Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Magnetic Bubble Dynamics in Nanodisks with Perpendicular Magnetic Anisotropy
Award.AbstractNarration:
****NON-TECHNICAL ABSTRACT****
This award supports experimental nanomagnetism research at a women's liberal arts college with a small co-educational Ph.D. program. Nanomagnetism is a particularly exciting area of research due to its fundamental role in physics as well as its potential technological applications. The development of advanced nanotechnology enables the manipulation of materials at the nanoscale to realize new functionality. The research proposed here is to design, fabricate and study novel magnetic nanodisks with perpendicular magnetic anisotropy. This will be accomplished by employing the most advance tools of experimental science: nanofabrication, high-resolution magnetic imaging, time-resolved synchrotron x-ray imaging with high temporal and spatial resolutions, and micromagnetic simulations. This research is expected to provide a new understanding of spin dynamics in nanomagnets, shed light on a variety of fundamental physics topics in nanomagnetism, and widen the scope for dynamical experiments in nanomagnets. This project will also provide undergraduate and graduate students an in-depth research experience and supportive mentoring. In addition, the PI will develop an interdisciplinary nanoscience course and an interactive website to educate the public about the achievements of young women scientists.

****TECHNICAL ABSTRACT****
This award supports experimental nanomagnetism research at a women's liberal arts college with a small co-educational Ph.D. program. The research proposed here is to study magnetic bubble dynamics in nanodisks with perpendicular magnetic anisotropy (PMA). The magnetic bubble state, a stable bi-domain configuration existing in nanodisks with PMA, consists of a circular domain wall that separates the nanodisk into two magnetic domains of opposite out-of-plane magnetizations. The nontrivial topological structure in the magnetic bubble is expected to result in novel spin dynamics with potentially new technological applications. To probe the magnetic bubble dynamics, time-resolved photoemission electron microscopy (TR-PEEM) with a 90 ps time resolution and 100 nm spatial resolution will be used. The unique motion of a ground-state magnetic bubble and the switching between the ground and excited states of the bubbles will be investigated. The non-linear spin dynamics in the excited bubble state and current-induced bubble dynamics will also be explored with the intent of developing a magnetic bubble-based spintronic device. This project will also provide undergraduate and graduate students an in-depth research experience and supportive mentoring. In addition, the PI will develop an interdisciplinary nanoscience course and an interactive website to educate the public about the achievements of young women scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Magnetic skyrmions, a specific type of magnetic bubbles with topologically protected spin textures, not only have rich physics as a topological phase of matter (2016 Physics Nobel Prize), but also can behave like stable quasi-particles that can be manipulated with very low electric currents. Therefore, magnetic skyrmions have potential to be utilized as carriers of information in future devices with extreme low-power consumption. Skyrmions have been observed in various materials but usually at impractically low temperatures. From an applied point of view, it is important to find magnetic systems that can host magnetic skyrmions at or above room-temperature, while at the same time minimizing skyrmion size. The PI’s group and collaborators focused on inversion asymmetric magnetic multilayers with perpendicular magnetic anisotropy, where the interplay of the Heisenberg exchange interactions, dipolar interactions, magnetic anisotropy, and interfacial Dzyaloshinskii-Moriya interactions enables forming and stabilizing magnetic skyrmions at room temperature. Utilizing magneto-optic Kerr imaging, we also investigated the motion of magnetic skyrmions when driven by electrical currents in a magnetic field. We observed that the topological charge gives rise to a transverse motion on the skyrmions, i.e., the skyrmion Hall effect, which is in analogy to the transvers motion of electrically charged particles in ordinary Hall effect. Our results may potentially lead to further technological applications in Spintronics and data storage.

This nanomagnetism research program funded by this award at Bryn Mawr College was also integrated with a multi-layered education and outreach program. Through the research activities supported by this award, opportunities of research in nanoscience and magnetism were provided to over twenty students (5 graduate students including 1 woman and 1 Hispanic, and 18 undergraduate students including 17 women and 1 Hispanic), especially those underrepresented in STEM fields. Through this project, an upper-level undergraduate course and three upper-level undergraduate laboratory course modules were developed to systematically introduce basics and frontier research results in solid state physics and nanoscience. The outreach activities to K-12 students and general public enabled by this project included leading STEM workshops for Philadelphia local middle school girls, coaching three different Junior FIRST® LEGO® League Lego teams of local elementary school children aged between 5 and 9 for themed engineering challenges, and working with women undergraduate students to educate general public about magnetism in the Philadelphia Science Festival.
